If I am an injured workman, under this Bill I am going to be faced with possible death, blindness and loss of a limb on the one hand, or starvation on the other. As the Bill stands, unless an injured workman follows the treatment prescribed by his registered medical practitioner, he runs the risk of forfeiture of benefit. I was rather sorry to hear the statement by the hon. and learned Member for Brighton (Mr. Marlowe) with regard to the unmarried wife. He put forward a case in opposition to ours, without an ounce of sympathy in it and full of legal jargon. One has to be among the working class to understand the punishment of forfeiture of benefit. Only the working man who relies on his income week by week to make ends meet, appreciates what forfeiture of benefit means. The Bill says to an injured miner who may be receiving benefit of£4 10s. a week and who wants natural healing or unorthodox healing, "You face death, or loss of a limb, or possible blindness on the one hand, or forfeiture of benefits on the other hand." I ask, is that fair? I go further. A wealthy person who wants to follow unorthodox medical practice is free to do so by paying 5, 10 or 20 guineas. What is 100 guineas to a man if he can save his daughter's life—if he can afford it? A poor working man, under this Bill, could not do it. He is faced with starvation or possibly the loss of his own life. A logical case can be made out from this Bill of one law for the rich and one law for the poor. I have heard hon. Members opposite say that any person who desires to practice unorthodox treatment can do so by going through the medical schools. The other day I heard two doctors talking in the smoke room. One agreed with the other. They said the one necessary qualification for becoming a doctor is£2,000. It is not necessary for unorthodox practitioners to go right through the school of orthodox practice. That is quite true. Take the case of the Edinburgh clinic where there is a four years' curriculum which includes the study of anatomy, physiology and all the basic requirements to enable the students to go through their profession. I heard one medical practitioner say to an osteopath, "What about a tubercular joint? You would damage a tubercular joint if you manipulated it without the necessary knowledge." I submit that an osteopath
would not run the risk of wrongly manipulating a tubercular joint.
We are not asking for what is unreasonable in this Amendment. I know we will be up against considerable opposition by the prejudiced school of the medical practitioners. I do not wish to be unreasonable. We are not submitting a case for quacks. I want to put that quite bluntly, because the natural response to the proposal that unregistered practitioners should have a right to treat injured workmen is that it involves quacks. I have been very closely associated with unregistered practitioners, and I know they are prepared to deal effectively and in an organised manner with the aspect of quacks. They are prepared to lay down a standard of education and knowledge, which they would generally recognise, and this Amendment seeks to protect the Minister on that particular point.

We only want such unorthodox medical practitioners to be recognised as can comply with whatever standard qualifications the Minister may set down. I know perfectly well that I shall be assailled by individuals wanting to support the registered medical practitioners with regard to very high standards of qualifications, the profound knowledge of the registered medical practitioners, claims to high knowledge and the study of the sciences, and so forth. In reply to that I say that the test of efficiency is the result, and it is the patient, the layman, who knows best whether he is entitled to the treatment of one school or another. From all the experience through which I have gone I know that I have a very strong inclination indeed. I support the unregistered medical practitioner. I submit that, unless my right hon. Friend the Minister gives this freedom of choice to the patient he will, in my opinion, be acting brutally and in a barbaric manner, having regard to the unfairness with which he would face the injured workman.

Any. scheme which provides for giving compensation for disablement as a result of injury must include some test to distinguish whether a disablement is the result of the injury or whether it is the result of something else. Here we have to consider the case which arises where the cause of the disablement is not
the injury but the refusal of the man to do anything about the injury. In the Workmen's Compensation Act there was a similar provision. Whilst I recognise it is necessary to provide some power in a Bill to be able to stop compensation of the man who just will not cure himself, and who just will not take the advice which would enable him to be cured, it is nevertheless a most dangerous power. In the Workmen's Compensation Act the provision was, that compensation could be discontinued—if I remember the exact words—if a man deliberately and unreasonably refused to accept medical advice. In my practice under that Act I came across a good many cases where the insurance companies' doctors used to go into the witness box and say," This man will be cured by operation. If he will submit to this operation his disability will end." That used to happen under the Workmen's Compensation Act. Quite often county court judges were most sympathetic about it and used to come to the conclusion that that was right, and that the man really was being unreasonable in refusing the operation. In the large majority of cases in which I have known that to happen, where, owing to compensation being stopped, the man did submit himself to the operation, the medical advice turned out to be quite wrong. It was very striking, the number of cases where you came back to the court and found that the operation which the man himself refused had only a little worse. I. think possibly one of the reasons is this, that there is very little medical which is much good unless it has the confidence and co-operation of the patient. Therefore' I would say, whatever the doctor may say in a very large number of this sort of cases, a man will get far better results from a nature cure in which he believes, and with which his mind co-operates, than he will from medical treatment of which he disapproves. Therefore I think the power is necessary. When it comes to drawing up the regulations—particularly the regulations for penalties under Clause 66—and when it comes to administration, the utmost care should be taken that this will not be administered oppressively
May I ask the hon. Member if he has not observed that the point he is making is covered by Subsection (4) of this Clause?
I should not have thought it was.
"Calculated to retard his recovery."

I should have thought the question of the administration of the regulations, which this Clause contemplates, is a matter which comes directly under this, and it is under those regulations that care should be taken to give as much freedom as possible to the man who genuinely wants to get well if possible, while at the same time retaining power to deal with the man who deliberately does not want to.
That is Subsection (4).

This Amendment has been discussed with great sincerity and a case has been put forward with much vigour by three of my hon. Friends on this side of the House. I will straight away address myself to a point of considerable substance made by my hon. Friend the Member for North Battersea (Mr.Douglas).Clause 66, which is the penalty Clause, empowers the Minister to make it an offence not to comply with a regulation. Of course, the Minister never had the smallest intention-of preparing a regulation which would make it an offence punishable by the criminal law for any workman to fail to comply with directions given under a regulation. There is, on the Order Paper, in the name, amongst others, of my hon. Friend the Member for North Battersea, an Amendment to Clause 66 of this Bill, which puts that within the power of the Minister. I can now say with the authority of my right hon. Friend that we propose to accept that Amendment, that is to say, an Amendment which provides that it shall be an offence not to comply with a regulation other than a regulation requiring a workman to submit to medical treatment. I do emphasise that the Minister never at any time intended any such failure to comply on the part of the workman should be a criminal offence. That point, in my submission, goes with the acceptance of that Amendment. That point, left as it was, was a point of substance, and that is the answer to it. It is also the answer to the other complaint which he made, that a work-man might be sold up if he did not comply with the regulation requiring him to submit to medical treatment. I do
not know of any provision under the Act—always excepting that Amendment to Clause 66—which could lead to that result. I can assure my hon. Friend the apprehensions which he had were entirely groundless and the Amendment will put that beyond any doubt.
What do the words objected to really provide? They propose simply and solely that a workman who submits himself to medical examination shall do so in these circumstances: that the medical examination shall be with the object, in the first place, of determining the effect of the relevant injury. No complaint was made about that, no observations were directed to it at all, by my hon. Friends who have spoken on the Amendment. It is then stated that the second object—a surely not unreasonable one—shall be to enable the Ministry's doctor to try to make up his mind what would be helpful to the workman in his injured state, and what treatment would be appropriate to his injury. Surely it can-not be reasonable to try to exclude that as one of the objects of a medical examination, once you have a medical examination at all? That is the primary and obvious purpose of all medical examinations, and if you exclude that purpose there is no reason at all for a man to be medically examined.
Hon. Members are so ready to see sinister intentions in various provisions of this Bill. In point of fact, it is surely to the workman's advantage that somebody should medically examine him with a view to trying to find out what medical remedies will be of service to him. Surely that is not a thing which could be decried—on the contrary, it is a laudable purpose, which the workman should be glad of. It is to be remembered, after all, that in the great majority of cases the examination will be of a physical injury which has caused disability or loss of faculty. How can you set about trying to cure a workman unless you have had an opportunity of examining him, and trying to make up your mind how to treat his injury?
That is all that the words complained of enable the doctor to do. They say no more than that one of the purposes of the medical examination to which the workman—without any complaint on the
part of anybody—is required to subject himself shall be the attempt to discover what would be helpful to cure the injury from which he is suffering.
Before the hon. and learned Gentleman leaves that point, will he read the item we are dealing with in conjunction with the next paragraph?

The next paragraph, I would point out, is not the subject of the Amendment at all. In my submission, it is a nonsensical way of looking at it to complain because the medical examination to which the work-man is required to submit himself is to be directed, as to one of its two objects, to finding out what would be a satisfactory way of treating his injury. To cut those words out makes the medical examination completely pointless.
Leaving aside the Amendment to Clause 66 to which I have referred, what are the consequences which can ensue to the workman if he refuses to accept the advice of the doctor? The doctor, after all, is out to try and cure him, but suppose the workman, perhaps animated by the sentiments expressed by my hon. Friend the Member for North St. Pancras (Mr. House), refuses to accept his advice. What is the worst that can happen to him? All that can happen to him is that; if he does it without reasonable cause— not otherwise—his benefit can be suspended; he forfeits his right to benefit. If he does not agree that he had no reasonable cause and wishes to test the matter, he comes before the insurance officer. After hearing what the workman has to say, and after considering the views he has advanced and all the circumstances which are relevant, the insurance officer asks himself, "Had this workman, in these circumstances, reasonable cause for refusing to accept the doctor's advice?" I cannot say in advance what a particular insurance officer would say, but I can conceive that, if he had before him a workman who held very strongly the opinions voiced by my hon. Friend, he might very well take the view that that was a reasonable cause.

Clearly the Bill is perfectly satisfactory as it is drawn in that all it provides is that if a workman, having no reasonable cause for so doing, refuses to carry out a doctor's bona fide advice given as a
result of the medical examination to which the workman has subjected himself, in those circumstances and not otherwise, the workman shall forfeit his right to benefit. If he disagrees with the decision that he had no reasonable cause, he can take the matter up and litigate it before the insurance officer. Surely, in administering this scheme, there must be some machinery to try and ascertain what medical treatment the workman who has sustained an injury should submit to? That is the least that can be said to be reasonable. If there is no such machinery, nothing can ever be done to assist the workman who has been injured, and no steps can be taken to cure him. This is for that purpose—to try to cure him, to restore him to health, and to give him back his full working capacity. I ask the House to say that this Amendment should be negatived.

I want to make two other observations. It all depends upon the regulations that are made. My right hon. Friend, and all hon. Members, know that under Clause 60 of the Bill an Industrial Injuries Advisory Council is to be set up. Under that Clause, when the Minister proposes to make regulations, he has to take the advice of, and submit his Regulations for consideration by, the Advisory Council, which will include experts well qualified to judge of these matters. That is one safeguard—the Regulations will not be made without thought and consideration by experts in that particular department of medicine. Not only that, but when the Council have passed the Regulations, they must still be submitted to a negative resolution of this House, so that this House will have a check on them. It is most unlikely, in fact it is impossible, that any Regulations could be made which it is unreasonable that the workman should be required to submit to.

There are all these safeguards—negative Resolution, careful examination by the Advisory Council of experts, and then, if the workman still persists in refusing to comply with the Regulation or in refusing to follow the advice which a doctor gives him, he has a further chance of showing that he has some reasonable ground—I do not say a perfect ground, but a reasonable ground— for his attitude. That is all that this Clause does. I submit to the House that it could not reasonably do less, and that the Bill would be completely unworkable
—this whole elaborate insurance scheme would be unworkable—without some machinery of that sort. I submit that, as it is framed, the Bill creates machinery which is in fact apposite and suitable to deal with the kind of problem that will arise. They are not, in the great majority of cases, diseases which are unknown, or whose causes may give rise to a great deal of medical controversy. The majority of cases are physical injuries which will require surgical treatment, or at any rate treatment of a well-recognised type, which can be recommended after an examination by the doctor. These words provide that the workman must submit to medical examination for that, including other purposes. I ask the House to reject the Amendment.

I have not been fortunate enough to hear the bulk of the discussion on this Amendment, neither was I fortunate enough to be a Member of the Standing Committee on this Bill, and therefore I intervene here with some trepidation. The Solicitor-General said that the workman should have some reasonable ground for refusing treatment, and he said that of course there must, quite naturally, be some machinery in the Bill providing for the workman to be examined and to have any treatment necessary for his cure. He also said, and I do not think he recognised the full significance of his words, that the bulk of the cases were of physical injuries resulting from accidents. But an injustice, even in one case, resulting from an industrial disease or from a nervous ailment like a neurosis subsequent to a physical accident, is still an injustice. Machinery should be available by which a man should be able to express his views.
I have a great deal of sympathy with the views expressed on this Amendment. A great deal of this anti-medical prejudice that exists is the aftermath of the conditions that have been allowed to exist. Workmen in the past have been examined by a particular set of doctors with a particular mind. Their object has always been to try to see, first, whether the man was malingering—a thing that does not really exist—or whether the man was trying to prove that his physical injury, or disease was due to an accident, whereas the Ministry of Pensions tried to pretend that it was not. Medical education needs
revision from top to bottom. Assessment of disability resulting from diseases or accident has not been taught up to the present in our best medical schools. I suppose I shall get kicked by the medical profession, as I usually do when I say this outside.
But even if what has been said is true, even if the medical profession in the past has made mistakes, even if it is true that some nature cures in exceptional cases have produced results the trained man has not produced, the fact remains that the workman is entitled to the best trained professional medical treatment he can get. No untrained treatment is sufficient. The ordinary workman is entitled to the very best advice, diagnosis, and treatment he can get, and the Government are entitled to provide machinery and means whereby that workman shall receive the best advice possible; and I fail to see why any scheme to which all workers contribute, and the public through the taxes also contribute, should not lay down the rules and regulations for the appropriate treatment of every individual, on a broad scale. Treatment must be of the best.
My difficulty is to know whether the Minister is going to get the men who will be adequate to give the medical treatment needed. I see machinery available for the examination of a man by some doctor; I see no machinery yet available, or in the making, to ensure the workman is to get that sympathetic handling and diplomatic advice he needs when he is perturbed, perhaps, by two different opinions—perhaps, two trained opinions; perhaps, an untrained opinion and a trained one—as to his proper treatment. But the fact remains that the workman, as I said before, should have the best treatment. I have had considerable experience of seeing workmen badly treated by doctors. They ought to have doctors associated with the work I am doing, and receive proper handling, sympathetic handling, with the case properly explained to them.
If the patients refuse treatment they can come back again later on, and in 99 cases out of 100 they come to realise, at last, that they have come into an atmosphere where they believe they will have the best done for them. I am only asking that the machinery to be provided in this Bill should be for treatment of that description. I am saying that the
workman is entitled to the very best treatment available, in his illness at the acute stage, and, later, in the chronic stage of his disability. If the Minister sees the type of medical man who is to do this work is of the right type—not of the type who represent his Department: God knows how some of them get there!— if he sees he gets doctors of the right type, he will be doing the workman a great deal of good, and I, personally, hope there will be machinery to see he gets the right type of doctor to give the workman a square deal, which he has not had in the past.

I want to speak briefly in favour of this Amendment. The words in the Clause about '' appropriate '' treatment occur again in Subsection (2b ).I cannot in my own experience remember any group of doctors who would agree on what, in many cases, is appropriate treatment. For that reason alone, to include that phrase in this Clause seems to me indefensible. The Solicitor-General spoke of treatment of well recognised types. What may be recognised now was probably not recognised years previously and may not be recognised in years to come. The medical profession is something which is very fluid. It is perpetually changing in its theories, and to tie ourselves to phraseology of this sort, I think, is inappropriate.
I should like to refer in this respect" to a quite substantial minority of the people of this country who do not believe in medical practice, in allopathic or homeopathic treatment, but who have gained benefit from other methods of treatment. Some have already been mentioned, but I should like to refer to that body of people who would not submit to medical treatment because of their religious principles. I am thinking, amongst others, of that body known as Christian Scientists. It is compulsory under this Bill that people like that must submit to medical treatment. Surely, it cannot be the intention of the Minister to penalise those who wish to employ other methods of healing. The Solicitor-General, as I recall, said that all those people who do submit themselves to medical examination should also submit themselves to "treatment of well recognised types "; and he, on that score, contended that the latter part of the Clause should stand.
What is recognised today is not recognised tomorrow is it the intention of the Minister, may I ask, that those people who do not submit themselves for medical treatment shall not be penalised? Can he give me an assurance, for instance, that when the Regulations are brought into force people who wish for forms of treatment other than medical treatment will not 'be penalised in any way? If that assurance can be given, it will satisfy the purpose with which the Amendment is being moved.

The Minister summed up his views about this on the Committee stage in the following words: I think hon. Members will agree that the provisions of the Bill should be made such as to persuade the man to do the things which axe necessary in the interests of his own recovery. That is the real point. In this new industrial chapter in workmen's compensation do we still think it necessary to take powers, and, in this case, to impose a financial penalty to persuade a man to do what he does not want to do? I suggest that that is part of the old chapter of workmen's compensation. We want to persuade a man under this Bill by methods which are different in principle from the old methods of having insurance companies trying to reduce financial liabilities by the aid of medical practitioners who are their servants. We require good doctors, and I. agree with the hon. Member opposite that we have not enough good doctors. The right thing to do is to press forward to get them. Hon. Gentlemen opposite who have spoken in favour of this Amendment certainly cannot want a State medical service because that would deny to the injured workman a choice of doctor which is, quite rightly, what he desires. Are we to assume that all these nature healers mentioned by the hon. Member for North St. Pancras (Mr. House) will in fact be in the State medical service?
I believe that the House, having heard the hon. Member for North St. Pancras, must see that this financial penalty to make a man do what he does not want to do is incongruous with the rest of the Bill. I hope that the Minister will state a little more clearly what appeal the man has. This Clause is badly drawn. The penalties are tucked away in Clause 66, and any appeal which the man has against any
of these instructions, if I may call them such, is not in that Clause. I am not at all satisfied. I believe that this is an interference with the liberty of the subject, which is not needed under this new principle of workmen's compensation.

We have had a long discussion upon this matter which is one of great importance. It is perhaps difficult for us to approach this problem in considering the context of the Bill in the spirit under which this service will have to be administered if it is to be a success. In the past, when a man received an injury, he was requested by the employer to attend at a certain place to be examined by a gentleman, if I may say so with respect to the doctor Members here, who was known as a compensation doctor—partly or fully employed by insurance companies and others, and not strictly employed for purely medical purposes. Under this Bill when a man receives an injury and makes a claim for benefit, we take power to enable the medical officer acting for the Ministry and for the service to require the man to be examined in order to assess the effects of the injury and to suggest and advise proper treatment.
Hon. Members opposite speak about personal liberty. By Acts of Parliament passed by them in the last 30 years the right to request a man to go for examination has been given to the employer, and they object to it being given to the men under a new service of this kind. Under present Acts if employers ask a workman to attend on a certain day for examination and he does not do it, they say "We will stop your compensation and you will have to go to court to get it back." Here obviously we will have our own doctor and the man will have his doctor and there will be consultation between the two. Most of the cases concerned here are physical injury or industrial diseases and we all know the kind of cases I mean, cases like hernia, nystagmus, pneumoconiosis. With respect to the hon. Member for North St. Pancras (Mr. House) and the hon. Member for North Battersea (Mr. Douglas), who have spoken this evening with all sincerity, I want to make it clear that where a man is ordered treatment in respect of industrial injury or industrial diseases and he refuses to undergo that treatment payments are suspended. Speaking as one who was injured, I think
that guidance and discipline in a certain measure are for all of us essential. I do not think workmen will object to that.
Sometimes it will be that a man will say, "I object to this treatment, so I refuse to undergo this operation." Sometimes it is a minor operation and sometimes it is a major one. When a refusal like that is made to the insurance officer he is empowered to suspend payments, but when payments are suspended there is a right of appeal. The appeal is to a local tribunal presided over by a chairman, who has legal qualifications, sitting with two assessors and two other members of the tribunal, one of whom is drawn from the employers' panel and the other from the workmen's panel. That will be an infinitely better tribunal to decide matters of this kind than any court of law, because there will be brought to each case human experience and understanding. I am satisfied it is going to work well.
We have heard with great respect and great regard the expressions of opinion of the hon. Members for North St. Pancras and North Battersea, but I would say that the matters which they mentioned as falling within the scope of this Bill will be infinitesimal. If there be such cases where a workman is a conscientious objector he can go to a tribunal and say, "I will not accept that treatment because I have conscientious objections." The tribunal if it is satisfied that a good case has been made out can agree, while beyond the tribunal is the Commissioner. I think, therefore, we have taken every reasonable precaution to see that no injury is done. I will tell the House what is now the real trouble. The real trouble has been that appropriate treatment has been left too long. For the first few months after a man was injured very often the doctors were involved in a struggle as to whether he would get compensation or not, not whether he got better or not. I believe that in a scheme of this sort administration is important, but do let us realise that the Ministry of National Insurance and the insurance officer working schemes of this kind have no interest in denying a man his compensation or payment under this Bill.
We have a real interest in seeing that he gets fair treatment and fair play, and for the first time in a Workmen's Compensation Act it will be our concern to see
that a man gets not only what he is entitled to receive, but that also he is encouraged and helped and advised to secure treatment. I would remind the House that the Bill to provide a complete national health service will bring to all, including the injured, all that is best in medical science and knowledge.

Pending the development of a national health service, which will take some time, may I ask my right hon. Friend where he is going to get his rehabilitation centres in order to provide adequate rehabilitation and treatment for the men whom he intends to compel to have certain treatment?

We certainly cannot provide a full scheme until it is ready. In the meantime, we have our miners' rehabilitation centre in South Wales. I do not think we are asking for anything that is unreasonable, and I can give the House an assurance that we have no desire to penalise or persecute workmen. All we desire to do is to develop the rehabilitation service fully, so that we can cure them, and set them up in independent life.
Will my right hon. Friend give an undertaking that the regulations will be framed so that those who have a conscientious objection to the treatment prescribed may not be obliged to take it?

I have said already that the regulations, when they are made, will have to be submitted to the National Advisory Council. They will advise me as to whether the regulations are such that I ought to carry them out. After that, the regulations will be laid on the Table, and. this House will have an opportunity of discussing them. I am quite certain that cases of this kind are best settled on their merits, and I shall design the regulations with a view to enabling the tribunal to deal with the merits of each case.

I am rather puzzled as to what this is all about. I agree with much of what has been said, but what does the Amendment mean? Subsection 1 (a) of the Clause gives authorities power to order an examination for the purpose of determining what is the best treatment. The Amendment says that there must not be that examination and that the words
… all the treatment appropriate to the relevant injury or loss of faculty, should be deleted. It appears, then, that you allow those words to be taken out of the Clause, but that you do not allow an examination prior to treatment. That is my reading of what the Amendment means. Therefore, I do not see why we should have had to listen to the very long speeches which have been made on this point, almost entirely from supporters of the Government.

I am doubtful what the Minister intends in this Clause. Subsection 4(a) of the Clause, which my hon. Friend is seeking to delete, says: any directions given him by the medical practitioner in attendance; and The Minister referred to cases of hernia, and mentioned minor operations. I must speak frankly. I accept that on the question of amputations and other operations, this Act is not going to put the workman in any worse position than he is in under the present compensation Act. A workman can today, on a doctor's note, state that he is going to refuse amputation on any part of his body; he can also get a doctor's note to say that an operation would be prejudicial to his health, and he can still continue to draw his compensation without any disqualification attending to it. Am I to understand that under this Clause, the manner of compensation is to be left to a tribunal, to interpret whether a doctor's recommendation is or is not a proper treatment. The doctor may recommend that a man may go through an operation for hernia. On the other hand the man may say '' I can carry out my work all right with a truss." Are we going to say that because the doctor certifies that this man is to have an operation, and the man refuses, that we will stop his compensation until he goes on the operating table and subjects himself to the knife?
This matter ought to be cleared up, and we ought to be given some indication of what the rights of the workmen are in relation to amputations and operations. It is a serious question. I have always held, even under the Workmen's Compensation Act, that a man's body is inviolate, and that he himself is the determining factor whether he will have a limb taken off or an operation performed on him or not. Having made that point, I
must say that I do understand the Minister's point of view in other matters. If a man has a fracture and is recommended for orthopaedic treatment, then I think that man ought to go and see to it that his bones get moving again in order to get him back into employment. I do, however, feel very disturbed about that part of the speech where the Minister has spoken about leaving a tribunal to determine whether a man should or should not subject himself to a particular course of treatment, and I would most certainly ask the Minister to try and set our minds at rest on these two particular points.

Would it not be possible to include somewhere in this Clause the words "if there is good cause ''? There is an equivalent phrase in the National Insurance Bill and it does seem to me to satisfy the case where an individual may have some particular scruples for objecting to medical treatment.

The argument put forward by the right hon. Gentleman is one of the most astonishing this House has heard. He began by saying that over a good many years of what I understood him to mean Tory legislation the system has been one under which empoyers were entitled to nominate their own doctors. I gathered from the way he said this that he regarded the system as objectionable. His deduction, however, from then on, was a rather surprising one, because he went on to say that this objectionable system was one which he was going to incorporate in the Bill and the regulations would be more stringent.
I never said anything of the kind.

I do not think there can be any doubt about it, because that is what I understood him to say, and that is how I understood the right hon. Gentleman to be arguing his case. I understood him to make the point that it was under Tory legislation during the past 20 or 30 years, and the phrase that he used was to the effect that under the system the employer nominated the doctor. Now the position here is, and it will become more so as the country comes increasingly under State employment, the employer will still nominate the doctor. Under this Bill there will, in fact, be a doctor appointed by the right hon. Gentleman,
and he will have virtual power of life and death over the workman. That to me is an intolerable position. I ask the right hon. Gentleman to look at this again. The present situation is this: If a man is dissatisfied he can at least get a contrary opinion from another doctor and weigh them one against the other.

The present position is quite clear. It is that a man must submit himself to an examination by the doctor appointed or employed by the employer. If he refuses, the employer has the right to stop benefit.
The doctor has not the right to prescribe treatment.
Of course he has.

A workman may also seek his own medical opinion and bring the matter before a court for decision. That is a very different situation from that which the right hon. Gentleman is creating under this Bill where the doctor may given directions which the workman is obliged to accept under forfeiture of benefit if he does not.
He can have recourse to the tribunal.

The right hon. Gentleman refers to his tribunal. I shall be careful to keep in Order on this, but it is impossible to consider this Clause without also considering Clause 32, which states specifically that in certain circumstances, such as failure to observe regulations under Clause 26, the man shall forfeit his benefit. It would be wrong for me to deal with Clause 32, which will be dealt with in due course, but the position is that if the workman does not obey the regulations, and, therefore, the directions which are given to him, he is liable to forfeit his benefit. That certainly is a far more stringent position than the workman is in under the present law.
Would not the workman still be entitled to produce his own medical certificate to a tribunal?

It must be remembered that we are dealing with a system where the witness, as it were, for the right hon. Gentleman, is his own doctor appearing before a Tribunal appointed by the right hon. Gentleman, a very different situation
from that which obtains under the present system where independent parties come before an independent court. [Laughter.] The Minister laughs, but perhaps I have greater respect for courts of law than he has. I would personally far sooner submit a case of this kind to an ordinary court of law than to any tribunal appointed by the right hon. Gentleman. It is perhaps not the moment to go into that. What concerns me in this matter is the position of the workman who is ordered to submit to an operation to which he may object. How many hundreds, even thousands, of cases there may have been where a man has been ordered an operation by a doctor but knew, inside himself, what was good for him, and has refused to undergo it, and in the end it has been proved that he was right and the doctor wrong.
Suppose, under the law which the right hon. Gentleman proposes to introduce, the position is that a doctor may say to a man, "You must submit to the amputation of a limb." If the man refuses, the right hon. Gentleman and the Tribunal may say to him, "Well then, no benefit." But for all we know the workman may be right. His refusal to submit to the amputation may well show that his experience of his own body is of considerably more importance than that of some doctor who has seen him, perhaps, for the first time in his life.
Is that the Tory idea of medicine?

I ask the right hon. Gentleman to remember the words of warning I gave him. He is entering a very difficult field, one upon which many people feel very strongly. I hope he will think that this matter is at least worthy of his reconsideration and that he will ensure that where a workman does not wish to submit to an operation he may at least refuse to do so without suffering any penalty under this Bill.

I should like, with the permission of the House, to speak again and, in view of what has just been said by hon. Members, to contrast the two positions, one under the Workmen's Compensation Acts and the other under the Bill. In the first case, the employer serves a medical certificate, and the workman serves a counter-certificate.The
matter then goes to a county court judge who has to determine which doctor is right. That is the position under the Workmen's Compensation Acts. Under the Bill, the workman is in a much better position.
Of course he is.

Suppose the Ministry's doctor says, "You ought to submit to this, that or the other treatment," and the workman does not agree. The workman does not agree, because he feels that he knows his own body better than the doctor knows it, or because some other doctor, or perhaps a personal friend, has told him that the Ministry's doctor is wrong; or the workman has a conscientious scruple or some well-grounded fear. He refuses, in any of those circumstances to comply with the direction that he should undergo a certain treatment.
What happens? His compensation can be stopped, but only if the insurance officer, having heard all the circumstances, not merely the opinion of the doctor on the workman's objection but the workman's grounds of objection, comes to the conclusion that the workman has no reasonable ground for refusing to submit to the treatment. Only in those circumstances can the workman be deprived of his compensation. Insurance officers may take different views. People approach these things in different frames of mind. It is left to the insurance officer, taking a reasonable and human view of the matter, to ask himself whether the workman, owing to his conscientious scruple, or fear, or contrary advice, or unfortunate medical experience in the past, has reasonable ground for refusing. If he has, the workman does not forfeit his compensation. If he has no reasonable grounds for refusing of any of those kinds, only then car it be said that he shall forfeit his compensation.
If we contrast those two positions, the workman is seen to be in a far more favourable position under the proposals of the Bill than he is under the Workmen's Compensation Acts, under which there is a dispute between doctors. If it is shown that the workman's doctor is wrong, the workman loses his compensation. Under the Bill, if the workman can show, not that the Ministry's doctor is wrong but that he has any other reasonable ground for not complying with what
the Ministry's doctor recommended, that is sufficient for the workman to be enabled to retain his compensation. He is in a far better position under the terms of the Bill than he ever was under Workmen's Compensation.
The tribunal will be appointed by the Minister. What guarantee is there that the insurance officer will go against the tribunal?

I am afraid that the Solicitor-General has made matters more complicated than they were before, and much worse from the point of view of the Government. At the present time, a man can appeal to a judge of a court of law, who has two medical men as assessors whom he can consult. Under the proposition now before the House concerning the, man who has disagreed with the Government's doctor about treatment prescribed, to whom is that man to appeal? Apparently to an insurance officer, according to the learned Solicitor-General— a layman. This layman has to decide on a purely medical issue.

The illustration given by my hon. and learned Friend the Member for Brighton (Mr. Marlowe) was a very good one. Suppose, for the sake of argument, a man goes before the Government doctor who advises amputation of a limb. It is well known, as' my hon. and learned Friend pointed out, that over and over again within the knowledge of medical men, certainly within the knowledge of laymen, nature has asserted herself in cases where amputation was prescribed and refused, and a limb has become perfectly well without any operation. Supposing in a case of that kind a man refuses an operation, the question of his compensation will be determined by a lay individual, an insurance officer. How is that insurance officer to determine whether or not the man has a reasonable objection? Is he in a better position to judge than the medical assessors in a court of law? What right has he to determine that this man has not a reasonable objection to having his leg amputated? He has no medical knowledge, no knowledge of the man's constitution, no knowledge of his heredity, no knowledge whatsoever on which to base a view and yet, according to the
learned Solicitor-General he has the right to refuse the man compensation simply because the man according to his own mind has a just and reasonable objection to what he considers to be a danger to life and limb. Previously I thought on the whole that the Government had a reasonable case, and that the man's compensation would not be stopped until he had appeared before a tribunal, but the hon. and learned Gentleman now says that it is not so, that it is now determined by a layman—
Subject to appeal.
Surely the Minister made it perfectly clear that the man has a right of appeal to a tribunal.

If the hon. Gentleman will give way to me, it would come under Clause 36 (2) which says that in the first place any question arising on a claim or an award of benefit shall go to an insurance officer, and from him to a local appeal tribunal or the Commissioner appointed in accordance with the Bill.

I still adhere to my view, and I consider that at the present moment, where the workman has the right to go before a judge in a court of law, who sits with a medical assessor on each side of him and advises purely from a professional point of view, he is in an infinitely better position than he would be under this Bill.

I hope the Government will resist this Amendment because I am afraid it is making nonsense of the whole Clause. I think the hon. Gentleman the Member for Torquay (Mr. C. Williams) is quite right in what he says. All this Amendment does is to suggest that the doctor should not be permitted to carry out examination for treatment, but it still permits treatment in the next Subsection, which makes complete nonsense of the whole thing. I think the hon. Member for North Battersea (Mr. Douglas) really ought to have amended the next Subsection if he wishes to achieve the result he does.

I understood the Minister to say that the insurance officer could stop the benefit and then the man would go before the tribunal. If the man has no savings and has a family that interval
may be a real hardship. Could the Minister not change the thing round and say that the benefit shall not be stopped until the tribunal has heard the appeal?

The position in. the Bill is that the insurance officer would certainly not issue instructions to a man to undergo treatment or an operation on his own initiative. The insurance officer would receive a report from a doctor that the Ministry had asked to see the man. He would then have the power to suspend payment of the benefit and let the man appeal to the tribunal or he would have the power—which I believe is the best course to pursue—without suspending benefit to refer the matter to the tribunal. With some experience of this kind of work in practice, I believe it is essential to have both powers. I agree entirely that the way in which the powers are used will be of very great importance to the success of the scheme, and the insurance officer has both powers. That would not deny us the right to suspend in some cases.
Why did the Minister not get up an hour ago and point put the perfectly simple fact that this Amendment would make complete nonsense and not affect the matter in the way we desire?
Amendment negatived.

I beg to move, in page 18, line 34, leave out from "recovery" to the end of line 38.
I hope this Amendment will meet with a little more success than did the previous one. The Minister has already put down an Amendment which goes more than half way to meet it The Solicitor-General indicated that he considered that the workman under this Bill had a safeguard in his right to appeal under Clause 32, Sub- section (2) in the words "reasonable cause." If that is so, I hope the Minister is willing to agree that this Subsection is sufficient if it states that it is the duty of the person claiming or entitled to injury benefit not to behave in any manner calculated to retard his recovery, without attempting to prejudice by regulations and rules of what is or of what is not "conduct likely to retard his recovery." That is all I am asking for in this Amendment so that the question of the man appealing can be completely at
large and not prejudiced by the production of a set of rules or the determination of some doctor that he ought to do such and such a thing.
I beg to second the Amendment.

I am sorry that we cannot accept the Amendment. As my hon. Friend has said, we have, as appears from the Order Paper, gone more than half way on the road he wants us to pursue. We have put down an Amendment, which, if accepted, would exclude paragraph (a) of Subsection (4). That is a paragraph which deals with directions which may be given to the man by the medical practitioner. That, we accept, should come out of the Bill. We accept that it should not be put upon the workman that he should be under a duty, in terms of Subsection (4) to comply with those directions. Therefore, in putting that Amendment on the Order Paper, we have, in my submission, met the substance of the point which is made by the Amendment of my hon. Friend. I ask the House to say that that is quite sufficient.
The only thing that remains is that the workman should be under a duty not to do anything that would retard his recovery, and under a duty to comply with any prescribed rules of behaviour. That is elastic, and is not in any sense a precedent. In connection with these prescribed rules, I would venture to repeat what I said a few minutes ago in regard to the previous Clause we were discussing. These rules have to be submitted to the Advisory Committee, which will consist of experts, who can give advice on the desirability of what the rules seek to bring about. Again the rules have to be laid before the House. Therefore, with these safeguards, it cannot be said to be in any sense a precedent for the workman to provide that it shall be his duty to comply with any prescribed rules of behaviour as set out in the relevant paragraph. They would be a general form of rules of behaviour, failure to follow which might retard a workman's recovery. The matter is left vague and elastic in order that there shall be reasonable discretion in the Ministry to try to guide the workman towards recovery. For those reasons I ask the House to reject the Amendment, in the knowledge that the next Amendment on
the Order Paper, which is in the name of the Minister, goes more than half way to achieving the purpose which my hon. Friend the Member for North Battersea (Mr. Douglas) has in putting down the Amendment. In those circumstances I ask the House to reject the Amendment.
Could the Solicitor-General answer this point: Do any prescribed rules of behaviour have to be laid before the House?
Yes, Sir.

As the Solicitor-General has said, paragraph (6), which he is proposing to leave in the Bill regarding prescribed rules of behaviour, is elastic. That is an almost inadequate description of an extraordinarily wide provision. It is all very well for the learned Solicitor-General to say, as he does so charmingly and plausibly, that such powers will only be used on the advice of appropriate committees, and in a most kindly, considerate and conciliatory fashion. Be that so, the House is being asked to give to the Minister, who may not always be the right hon. Gentleman, powers to prescribe any prescribed rules of behaviour which an injured workman breaks at the possible cost of losing his benefit for life. I would protest against such unnecessarily wide powers being given to a Minister merely on his undertaking not to use them.

That is surely an abdication by this House of its authority. It is surely abdication to do it when it is so unnecessarily wide. In circumstances such as those just suggested by the learned Solicitor- General—some such provision as "any conduct which there was reasonable cause to believe would retard his recovery "—there might be some cause for it, but there can be no cause for giving the Minister power to lay down any prescribed rules. It is possible that we might have a Minister less reasonable than the present one who objected, for example, to alcohol or tobacco. Under this Clause it would be perfectly open to him to lay down that no injured workman could smoke or drink or he would forfeit his benefit. That is an extreme case. I know perfectly well the Minister will say he is not going to do that. I would repeat that the fact that the Minister will not use excessive powers is no argument whatsoever for giving them..

I must confess I am not very satisfied with the reply given from the Front Bench opposite to this Amendment. I am quite sympathetic to the idea that there should be some sanction of a financial character where a man unreasonably refuses to undergo appropriate medical treatment, but we have already got that in Subsection (2) of the Clause. We have accepted a Clause under which Regulations may provide for requiring claimants to submit themselves from time to time to appropriate medical treatment for the said injury or loss of faculty.
In Subsection (4), which the hon. Gentleman the Member for North Battersea (Mr. Douglas) now wishes to curtail, it says: … it shall be the duty of any person claiming or entitled to injury benefit… not to behave in any manner calculated to retard his recovery. I agree with the hon. Gentleman the Member for North Battersea that Subsection (4) might very well end at that point because what does the Subsection as proposed by the Minister now to be amended proceed to say? Beyond that point it goes on to say: …and in particular to observe….(b) any prescribed rules of behaviour. Now the learned Solicitor-General has explained that "any prescribed rules or behaviour" does not mean rules of behaviour prescribed for the individual patient. The word "prescribed" under this Bill has a technical meaning, and if hon. Members turn to page 59 of the Bill, Clause 85, they will find a definition of the word: ' prescribe ' means, unless the context otherwise requires, prescribe by regulations. Therefore, it would appear that the rules of behaviour to be laid down under the Clause now under discussion are to be rules of behaviour laid down by regulation. The right hon. Gentleman will require a most elaborate code of regulations if he is going to prescribe by regulation codes of behaviour for patients suffering from an infinite variety of industrial injuries and diseases. I cannot therefore bring myself to believe that the words "prescribed rules of behaviour," in Subsection (3) of this Clause really mean rules of behaviour prescribed by regulations.
I am quite sure what the draftsman intended these words to mean was rules
of behaviour prescribed by a doctor for the individual case under consideration. If that be the true meaning of the words, then I say these words are really not necessary because we have already got, under Subsection (2) of the Clause, a provision compelling the man, subject to the penalty of loss of his benefits, to submit himself to appropriate medical treatment for the injury or loss of faculty.
You have also in Subsection (4) an obligation on the man, also subject to the penalty of losing his benefit, not to behave in any manner calculated to retard his recovery. I do not see why it is necessary to go beyond these two powers and take a third power to deprive a man of his benefit because he does not follow some rule laid down for his individual case by a doctor appointed and paid by the Minister. There may be many cases where the man" is told by the doctor, "I do not advise you to smoke." That is. just the doctor's advice; but, if he says, "I forbid you to smoke," and the man-is found enjoying a cigarette, he might be disqualified, if those words remain in the Clause, from receiving benefit, as one of my hon. Friends says, for the rest of his life. If the words remain in the Clause providing that a man must not behave in any manner calculated to retard his recovery, that should give sufficient power in the hands of the Minister, and, although I sympathise with the idea that there must be some financial sanction against a man who either refuses to undergo treatment or to behave in a way in which he ought to behave, I think the power asked for by this paragraph goes too far and that the Subsection is complete without it. I shall advise my hon. Friends, if the hon. Member for North Battersea presses the matter to a Division, to support him in the Lobby.
I am not sure that I understand the Amendment entirely, but on the elementary and fundamental maxim of law-making that no law should be made which is unenforceable, I should like to—

If the House will allow me to speak again on this Amendment, may I say that, having listened to the speeches, we have thought the matter over again and- we are taking steps to see that the Amendment is accepted?
Amendment agreed to.
Further Consideration of the Bill, as amended, adjourned—.[Mr. Mathers.]
Bill (as amended in Standing Committee and on recommittal) to be further considered Tomorrow.

publicwhip.major-heading: Orders of the Day — TRADING LICENCE (EX-SERVICE MAN'S APPLICATION)

speech.q: Motion made, and Question proposed, "That this House do now adjourn."— [Mr. Mathers.]

speech.p: On a point of Order. May I ask which Minister is to reply to this Debate on the Motion for the Adjournment? I gave notice a fortnight ago to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Food, and I do not see the hon. Lady here. I should like your guidance on this matter, Mr. Speaker.

It is not a point of Order for me. I cannot order a Minister to be here, but, if the hon. Gentleman continues with his speech, I have no doubt that the Minister will be here shortly. We have interrupted proceedings earlier than was expected.

Amid the welter of legislation which this House is called upon to pass, it is well for us, from time to time, to keep in mind the individual problems of the man in the street. The matter which I wish to raise on the Adjournment tonight concerns a grievance of one of my constituents. In the normal way, one tries to get satisfaction from a Minister by question and answer in correspondence, and if that fails the only remedy left is to raise the matter on the Adjournment. My constituent, Mr. R. Willey, of 101, Boundary Road, Newark was from the age of 16 until the beginning of the war engaged in the corn and animal feeding
stuff trade. He worked for some years for Messrs. J. Carter amp; Co., a firm of seedsmen in London, and was paid on a salary and commission basis. One of the terms of his agreement was that, in addition to selling for his principals, he could also deal on his own account. For the three years prior to the war he did so to the extent of something like£2,000 to£3,000 a year. On 3rd September, 1939, being in the local Territorial Yeomanry, Mr. Willey was called up and served in the Army for six years, four of which he spent as a prisoner of war.
When he came back he was 39 years of age, and he thought the time had arrived when he should have the opportunity of striking out for himself. He applied to the appropriate Ministry for a licence to deal in homegrown grain and animal feeding stuffs. His application was refused on two grounds, first, that he had not acted as a principal before the war and, secondly, that there was no evidence to show that, in that particular area, the services of an additional merchant were necessary. He then came to me and I took up the matter with the Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Food. I wrote and asked her to reconsider this case. I pointed out, first, that the applicant had had a long experience of the trade, that he had served six years in the Forces and that he was 39 years of age. But I failed to get any satisfaction. With regard to the first reason for refusal of the licence, as I pointed out earlier, my constituent had, in fact, acted as a principal in addition to representing this firm. I have not the slightest doubt that had he been in this country when the register was made, he would have been included in it. But it is the second reason which seems to me to be open to very strong criticism. To ascertain whether the needs of a particular area require an additional merchant, reference is made to a local wheat commitee, composed of four merchants, four millers and four farmers. Such action was taken in this case. One would have supposed that, when the Minister referred this case to the committee, the secretary of the committee would have called a meeting, that the committee would have discussed the case and that they would have forwarded a recommendation to the Minister. I wrote to the Minister and asked if she would let me know the names of the members who sat on the committee on this occasion. I
received what was, to me, a most peculiar answer. The Minister replied: The committee is not under the control of this Department, and I am not in a position to give the names of members who may have been present at a particular meeting. There appears to be some mystery as to how this decision was made. Were the farmers consulted? Were the millers consulted? What was the method of consultation? I understand that the committee was never called together, and that this recommendation which was submitted to the Minister, was the recommendation of the secretary after consultation with a few of the members. Perhaps when she replies, the Parliamentary Secretary will be able to assure me that she will look into this point, because it is very important. The importance of this point is that the equity of this committee rests in the fact that there are four of each— merchants, millers and farmers—and, therefore, if only four merchants were consulted, it would obviously be wrong.
But apart from that irregularity, and without imputing any wrong motives to any of the members of this committee, it seems wrong to me that members of a trade should have to sit in judgment on a man who wishes to enter that trade. A system of this kind is bound to be open to abuse, and, after all, this committee is in the nature of a tribunal. The Minister accepts their advice, and the essential thing in a tribunal is impartiality. It is very difficult to see how these committees can be impartial since some of their businesses might be affected by their decisions. What would it have meant, in fact, if this young man had been given a licence to trade? He would have been in competition with the merchants who sat on that committee. Starting out for himself after six years away at the war, he would probably have worked hard. We know many of those who stayed at home have not worked hard, and there has been no necessity for them to work hard; business has been so easy. He would undoubtedly have taken some of the business away from them. It also seems to me that the position confers a monopoly, and that is" a word which hon. Members opposite do not like. It seems to me to confer a monopoly on those people who were in the trade before the war.
If my constituent had been 23 or 24 years of age, it really would not have
mattered, but he is 39 years of age. He has done all this service for his country; he has had a long experience in this trade. He has the necessary financial backing, and I do not think he should be subject to this frustration. He is probably one of thousands who, during the time they were serving and during the time they were in captivity, were making plans for the time when they returned home, and it is this type of treatment which makes the ex-Service man so bitter. I beg the Parliamentary Secretary to reconsider this particular case and to look into the question of how this committee did its work. Also, would she please reconsider this particular Order, which I do not think is necessary now that the war is over? It was brought in as a wartime measure, and I think the need for it has now ceased.

speech.speakername: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Food (Dr. Edith Summerskill)
speech.p:
Although no doubt the hon. Member for Newark (Mr. Shephard) has a wide knowledge of the work of the Ministry of Food, I feel that perhaps the licensing procedure followed is not quite clear to him. I will explain to him the general licensing policy followed by the Ministry. It is based on the fact—and I ask hon. Members to realise how important this fact is—that food, raw materials, labour and transport are limited. Therefore, every individual who applies for a licence has to satisfy certain conditions. We found that it was very necessary to prevent the indiscriminate licensing of new businesses, until it could be shown that those businesses were necessary in the national interests. I want to explain to the hon. Member how we apply our rules, so far as the homegrown grain industry is concerned. An applicant, whether he is an ex-Service man or not, is given a licence automatically, if he can prove that he has been engaged in business as a principal. In a moment I am going to deal with the case of Mr. R. Willey which the hon. Member has raised, but that point must be borne in mind. We divide the applicants into two groups, and if those who are ex-traders come into what we call our priority group, those ex-traders are automatically given licences.Secondly, it must be proved that the particular work an applicant wishes to perform will be in the national interest and that, so far as the grain industry is concerned, there is a need for an additional approved buyer
in the area in which the applicant wishes to trade, in order to ensure the orderly marketing of the grain.
In considering these applications it is also necessary—and this is where the committee to which the hon. Member referred performs a useful function—for the Ministry to have reliable information, first as to the need of an approved buyer, and secondly as to the suitability of the applicant. I would remind the House that it is essential for the Ministry to be assured that these approved merchants have available all the facilities necessary for ready marketing, and to ensure that new licences are not issued to persons who will be unable to provide such facilities. It is necessary of course to move the grain rapidly from the farm. If transport is not available, then the farmers blame the Ministry of Food for being inefficient. Furthermore, it is necessary to have warehouses. The grain would have to be moved from the farm to a warehouse and may have to stay there for a short time until it can be transported to the buyer.
Is the hon. Lady aware that many of these merchants have no transport of their own?

Some of them have not, I agree, but I can assure the hon. Member the best approved merchants have, and those who have conduct their businesses perhaps more efficiently than the others. These factors are of course taken into consideration. Therefore, the Ministry has adopted the practice of obtaining recommendations from the local wheat committees covering the areas in question, and has taken those recommendations into account. I want the hon. Member to realise that it is not left to the wheat committee to make the final decision The committee does make a decision, and does advise us, but we can, if we like, revise that decision.
If the local wheat committee recommends that this man be given a licence, surely the Ministry would act on that.
Not necessarily.
Is there any point in asking for their recommendation?

Yes, certainly In the case we have before us, the local committee made a recommendation. The
hon. Member felt that his constituent, Mr. Willey, had not been treated fairly and communicated with the Ministry. I can assure the hon. Member that I investigated the case very carefully and quite objectively, and if I had thought that Mr. Willey had not been dealt with fairly, the decision would have been revised.

I am sorry to interrupt again, but most of my case was based on the fact, or rather the assumption, that this committee was never called together. Has the hon. Lady satisfied herself on that point? Is she satisfied that every member of that committee was consulted, and if so, what was the method of consultation?

I was explaining to the hon. Member the procedure which we followed—our normal practice—and then I was going to deal with the specific case of Mr. Willey. If he will have a little patience with me, I will explain exactly the procedure followed in Mr Willey's case. First, let me tell him about the local wheat committee. There are 53 of these committees in Great Britain. They were appointed originally by the Wheat Commission set up to administer the Wheat Act of 1932. The members are unpaid, and comprise local merchants, farmers and millers, and, therefore, since the hon. Member said just now that it was not fair for this potential merchant to have his future decided by other merchants, I would remind him that the committee is composed not only of merchants but of millers and producers also. I think I furnished the hon. Member with a list of the members of the committee, and if he looks at that list he will find that of the 12 members of the committee only four are merchants. It is, therefore, impossible for the merchants to have the last word.
I know the hon. Member has a great deal of knowledge of these matters, and I think he would agree with me that it would be in the interest of the producer to have a large number of merchants, because that would probably facilitate the transport of his grain. So, he cannot argue that the farmers would necessarily vote against Mr. Willey's acceptance. He queried the function of these committees, but I think he would agree with me, as he knows his own area, that these men are surely the best to advise us on local conditions. We have no power or control over their activities, and the meet-
ings of the committees are held in private. I remember that the hon. Member asked us who attended the committee which decided Mr. Willey's case. One could not possibly disclose a matter of that kind; it would be unfair to ask the committee who attended, because it would be very easy, in a fairly small locality, for those people to feel that, in another case, their hands would be tied. If in each case it was revealed who attended and how they voted, perhaps the committees, which have done excellent service during the war, would be reluctant to continue to serve the Ministry.

May I interrupt once again, because this is rather an important matter? I said I was given to understand that this committee never, in fact, met. The hon. Lady tells me that there are farmers and millers on the committee, and I agree that there are four of each, but if they were never consulted, would it be a fair decision for the secretary to send to the Ministry?

I think the hon. Member has been misinformed. At no time did we tell him that they never met. We have always said that they perform a useful function. I come now to Mr. Willey's case. In the first place, we interviewed Mr. Willey and then we asked the advice of the local wheat committee. They considered his case very carefully and then advised us—so they did meet in Mr. Willey's case. Mr. Willey applied in October, 1945, for a licence to trade as an approved buyer in home grown grain and feeding stuffs. He had served in the Forces from 1939, and he had served his country splendidly. We do not deny it. We recognise that well. We do not want to treat him badly, but the hon. Member will realise that there are other factors to be considered. The hon. Member said that Mr. Willey was engaged in the trade. He was certainly engaged in the trade, but he was employed by a firm of seed crushers from 1927 to 1933 as a salesman, and from 1933 to the outbreak of war, by a firm of agricultural seed merchants, as an agent. I repeat, as an agent. He was now seeking to become an approved buyer. He was now asking to be registered as a merchant, whereas before he was employed as an agent.
Exactly the same.
I am sorry, but I cannot agree that an agent to a firm of seed merchants is the same as an approved buyer.
What is the difference?

I am trying to explain if the hon. Member would only be patient. I did listen to him very quietly. When Mr. Willey was an agent to a seed merchant, he was, I agree, allowed to do a little trading. But if the hon. Member makes further inquiries from Mr. Willey, I think he will find that that trading was of a very minor character. If Mr. Willey had been working when the registration was made, he would not have qualified for registration as an approved buyer. He was interviewed by an inspector of the Home-Grown Cereals Division; and the inspector was very impressed. He realised that Mr. Willey was of the highest integrity. There was no question of that. The application was subsequently referred to Nottingham wheat committee, who reported that the area was already well served by existing approved buyers. There were already twelve approved buyers in Newark. That was what determined the decision of the Ministry of Food. We were advised that there were already a sufficient number of buyers there. It is essential also that we safeguard the existting tradesmen. It was on this ground alone that we could not grant Mr. Willey a licence. I hope that the hon. Member is satisfied. I can assure him we have investigated this case, and it was only because the area was adequately served that we had to refuse him this licence.

Will the hon. Lady look into this case, and assure herself that every member of that committee was consulted? I know the committee meet but I said that in this particular case the committee did not meet. That is the information I have. Further, may I ask how long is this farce going on? How long is it to be before a man of that age can start in business for himself?

When it comes to deciding who shall serve the country, and in what capacity, after the war, we cannot always take age into consideration. So far as the committee meeting is concerned no committee, of course, can ensure that 100 per cent. of its members
will turn up at a meeting. I cannot possibly guarantee that 1oo per cent. of the committee were there. How often do 1oo per cent. of the Members of this House turn up even on an Adjournment Motion of this importance? I will take steps to confirm what I have been told, but I cannot believe that responsible officials of the Ministry of Food would say that that Committee met and gave them that advice when the committee, in fact, never met.
What would be the quorum of the committee in this case? Of a committee of twelve how many would form a quorum?
The quorum of this committee is five.
If the committee consisted of only four, would it not be valid?
Certainly not.

Would it be valid if they did not meet at all? Would it be valid if the decision was conveyed to the Minister or officials by chatting in the market place? Would the hon. Lady consider that a proper way of dealing with this case?
No, I certainly would not. If the hon. Member can give me evidence that this committee never met, and that its business was conducted in the market place, I shall certainly examine it.
That is the information I have had.
Adjourned accordingly at Twenty-one Minutes past Ten 0'Clock.
